comments.commentBody:
Martin, that is not what I had in mind but, in fact, I loved Charlie Wilson's War. I remember my late friend Andy mentioning Philip Seymour Hoffman. I thought he was great. I wish I could have spent an evening in some tavern with him sipping bourbon. He died too young and too tragically.

Obviously you forgot my post when I related my father taking care of me. I'm thinking of putting MTF and you in a playpen. All that's missing would be the diapers.
But is Gendry still rowing?

A great many fantasy/sci-fi plots have historical--though often obscure--models.  Since I know little about China's history, I wouldn't have caught this one for a while.   The outlandish quality of fantasy--dragons and such--merely cloak the historical research these writers likely undertook to garner ideas for their novels.  And that's a positive not a negative.
The Romans did much the same (in a gradual fashion) by inviting the barbarians in to guard the city.

My thoughts exactly!  Not too long ago, Cersei helped enable the Faith Militant and the High Sparrow and tried to use them to do her bidding.  Look how well that turned out for her.  Now she's going to invite the Tyrell army into her city to get rid of the Faith Militant.  The modern day equivalent is bringing in one invasive species of animal or plant to eradicate another, then getting stuck with the new one.

In 1644, a popular peasant uprising was toppling China's Ming Dynasty. As the peasant army occupied the capitol, the Ming government invited their vassal the Manchurians inside the Great Wall to help crush the rebellion. Prince Dorgon came in with his bannermen (The 8 Banners) and did just that, and then they decided to stayed for another 268 years as Qing Dynasty.

With all these historical parallels, I couldn't help but scream at TV when Jamie and Cersei when they came up with this idea. I miss Tywin.
I can understand Jon's sullenness. The dude was dead, remember. Give him another week, ok?

"Now it seems romance might be in the frigid air of Castle Black. Tormund reacted to her arrival with the Wildling equivalent of a Looney Tunes wolf whistle."

Reminded me of a similar scene in "Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire" between Hagrid and Madame Olympe Maxime...

I think the 2000 Wildling army is referring to the numbers that Tormund can command and ask to go fight alongside Jon Snow.  There was a significant number of that initial army (like the Thenns - the cannibals) that are not going to join forces with anyone now that they are on the other side of the Wall.

Damn, that was one flammable temple. Maybe it's covered by their homeowner's (templeowner's?) insurance?
"the numbing suspicion that the net result of the Slaver’s Bay excursions and Meereen misadventures were to get Daenerys Targaryen back to where she was over four seasons ago: leading a Dothraki force....".
Yeah. Perhaps the whole point of the Mereen thing is to get ships and learn the difference between waging war and ruling a city.
Nice parallel between sisters (Yara Greyjoy, Sansa) reuniting with brothers and reminding them of what's at stake.
If I remember correctly, the wildlings were an army of 10,000 a few seasons back and now they're at 2000, maybe. Winterfell is a tough castle to take even with fair numbers. The army from the Vale (creepy Lord Robin's) had better get there in time.
Great episode but bring back Bronn please!
Yes! You got it just right! Go, Mother of Dragons!

The temple was likely made of thatch. The base was a stone base, but the temple itself looks like a thatch temple. It's definitely not metal or stone. So thatch will catch fire and burn
very quickly...quickly enough to let the Momma of Dragons
escape while frying a bunch of Khals.

The temple was mostly wood and thatchwork and covered
with skins...like a Yurt...a collapsible tent built by nomadic
people.

I was thrilled at Dany's power - not rescued by dragons or Jorah, but saving herself all by herself.  And Sansa, the strength that was stolen from her by that unforgivable wedding-night-rape, to see her so strong, it's so satisfying.  I think that the show is better than ever!
Great point. That might partly explain Kevan's reluctance and the Queen of Thorns' approval. Tywin (and Tyrion) wouldn't have gone for it.
And Yara telling off on Theon, and Margaery trying to prevent Loras from cracking under pressure.

Interesting how the female characters took charge of events in this episode.  Sansa browbeat Jon into agreeing to go after Ramsay.  Cersei schemed to use the Tyrell's army to get rid of the High Sparrow.  And of course, there was Dany walking through the fire and burning the Dothraki leaders alive.  Not a bad week for the ladies.

I must disagree. The ever-expanding big bang of George RR Martin's plot threads needs to come back together in a satisfying way at some point. The reunion of Jon and Sansa starts to accomplish this. So does Dany's fiery return to the top of the Dothraki food chain, and Theon and Asha's reunion. As a lover of the novels, I am surprised to say this is my favorite season so far.
As to what would be better than Wun Wun killing Ramsay? That's easy: Sansa going after him with a sword to the groin, then feeding him to his dogs (as an earlier commenter noted).

I agree. It seems obvious that if there is ever to be an end to the series (and books) some of temporarily triumphing evil characters must eventually make way and die for the main good characters to ultimately triumph.  The prophecy will show 3 heads of the dragon saving westeros - not only from itself but as the cycle demands - from the ice.  Remember that the premier theme of the show was that Winter is Coming.  When it comes - the dragons must fight it back.

Yeah, the quality of the writing (esp dialogue) has suffered due to George Martin not being involved this season, and no book to turn to for snappy dialogue.  George has vowed to stick to his knitting and finish  the sixth book.  Well he should.  The books are the main event, the show is a cartoon version of the books.  I hope he can get Winds of Winter out before he completely loses interest (which he is threatening to do, based on his comments)...

The quality seems cheaper than in past seasons, as wooden direction now accompanies the already wooden dialogue. It feels like painting by the numbers at this point, and I suspect that GoT will not age very well.
Yes, thank God no showing of travels to Castle Black, the mishaps, or whatever else they will encounter with a reunion with Jon Snow.
One more season at most. No way can they wrap GoT in six episodes.
The Grayjoy plot is back because Denarys needs the iron fleet to transport her hoard to Westeros

Terrific episode - I wish they were all this good. Wasting no time, it announced it was getting down to business when Castle Black's gate swung open and Sansa and Brienne marched in, the writers sparing us an interminable epic journey North. I almost fell off my seat.
It's been looking like that all season—the conversation between Davos and Jon last week was a particularly painful example.

Agreed.  As much fun as this most recent episode was, the dialogue this season has been rather pedestrian and the plotting not quite as original as one (well, OK, I) might hope.  But I guess that's inevitable with a show this popular.  You can't retain the loyalty of a large audience, even a relatively sophisticated one, if you repeatedly confound their expectations and challenge their understanding.  Television is mass entertainment, not avant-garde theater.
"Good soup" was the line.

The long awaited reunion:

Sansa : "This soup is good."

The soup may be good, but the dialogue is already beginning to look like it isn't.

I don't recall whether the heart to HEART juxtaposition affected my solve, but it is such an appropriate one that it may have been intentional, and was allowed to stand  as an exception that proves the rule.

You can browse my photos at www.pbase.com/macknight.

They're sorted by type. Merrilee's photos are also there.

I'd love to get well enough to do more nature photography. Fingers crossed.

David,
I apologized, so don't be so diacritical.

I like this one for spring. We have robins year-round in Yakima.

http://www.pbase.com/macknight/image/23303285

and Elke

Mac Knight- great pictures ! Love Calliope in her pink hat- she's adorable.
You are in our thoughts. We're crossing fingers, toes, eyes ....
Keep up your spirits.
One can learn to distinguish MONET from MANET at MOMA.

"The misdirection of “spiked” in the clue and the volley-ball-specific meaning of SET in the revealer will elude solvers unfamiliar with the sport."

True, but this is a Monday puzzle, a relatively easy time for solvers unfamiliar with a subject to learn new terms or have "aha" moments, which is (for me, anyway) part of why we do crosswords. N.B.: This was not such a case for me; my wife coaches volleyball.

Of all the classes I ever had in school, the one I disliked most was gym. And of all the awful things we had to do in gym, the thing I loathed the most was VOLLEYBALL.

But I got the entry easily from the clue; apparenly I had for some reason stored the knowledge that one of the worst things that happens in the game is called "spiking." {shudder}

But I had to wait until I read Deb's remarks to find out how the entry fit in with the SET theme.

This was a pleasant Monday puzzle of appropriate difficulty.

Can the 22A/10D crossing be considered a Natik (NIxON)?
The MONET/aNET --Claude/Edouard distinction, which was discussed on the blog a while ago, may be obscure to new solvers and KABaB is at least as legitimate as KABOB (or kebab or kebob).

he theme is cute, but I didn’t see it until I got down to the revealer, which was too late to be of help in completing the solve. (No help was needed.) . The misdirection of “spiked” in the clue and the volley-ball-specific meaning of SET in the revealer will elude solvers unfamiliar with the sport.

Viv,
Thanks for the encouragement. If they are all as delicious as this Berry was, I won't regret the annulment. Note, however, that I did not commit myself to solving every Sunday puzzle from here to eternity.

I trust, Viv, that you have either fully recovered or are well on the way to recovery.

This campaign promise is monumental. Some of our cities are finally fulfilling the promise of universal pre-K, but that is a drop in the ocean. There are many states, never mind cities, that do not even have universal full time kindergarten. The Headstart program only reaches out to a small percentage of low income pre-K youngsters, and the struggling low middle class are not within the narrow low income eligibility guidelines. Does Hillary have a new Education czar who has the vision to push and implement a new huge social policy that will inspire a nation and its representatives to pay for any portion of a new education venture that will uplift millions of families? Bernie talks about a lot of big ideas, but many are not sure he can make it happen; but can Hillary make it happen either?

Our neglect of our children, our neighbors, our own selves, is a uniquely American affliction. While it wasn't an epiphany when I heard in a very short radio report on rural California voters, an interview at 2:00 minutes caught my ear, not so much because the female voter is a Trump follower, but because of her beliefs on money and politics.

According to this voter, were it not for rich people, there would be no America. Clearly, in this rural California community that votes Republican consistently and, for a voter who favors Donald J. Trump, America's history, by way of its slavery roots, has no impact on this person's perspective. To this person and many like her, the wealthy made America what it is and they are still its backbone. How they became wealthy and why - the connection between much of American wealth, how it was accumulated and continues to be amassed - just don't figure into this equation. There is no awareness of a connection between American capitalism's reliance on a system of classes and racial sub-classes in order to function and, therefore, it just isn't a part of her awareness or millions of Americans like her, regardless of social or educational attainment. This "failure" is a feature of our system of government and, by extension, the most consequential failing of America's system of education.

We can break the cycle.
--
2016: White Voters And Racism In The Age of Trump And Sanders: http://wp.me/p2KJ3H-2fo

Very slow to get the theme today; I was trying word connections with the separate words in the theme answers, a word hidden somewhere and all I noticed was that a 3 or 4 letter word ended each,
one, all, able & lock, which didn't help a bit. When I finally got it with the reveal I was impressed by the vastly different things that could be set.

I certainly found this tougher than a Monday usually is, not a complaint, but it might have discouraged all these newbies that Deb is advising.
Problems that can't be paid for in the real world are not real solutions. He is done. It's time to move on.

The next President must be able to get new legislation through Congress. All these programs require legislative approval. Bernie Sanders is a dreamer who has spent his life on the fringes of politics. This is why mainstream politicians like Hillary Clinton are so important. Democrats hoping for election or reelection to Congress will benefit from having her at the top of the ticket. yes, that's how it works as long as we operate according to the division of powers set out in our Constitution.

It's a moving target, too. Not one and done with COLAs. There will be increasing automation, faster if there is a high national minimum wage. We must change the tax code, enforce it and redistribute to cover jobs that the market currently doesn't sufficiently value, but which need doing for the good of our social compact.

There are still three candidates in this election and it is the non-presumed candidate whose policy prescription for childcare, from infancy through college, makes the most sense and truly answers needs.

Affordable childcare is a mirage, without a significant change to the minimum wage when in most cities it costs as much to pay for childcare than it does to send a child to private school.

Bernie Sanders' proposal for free childcare, especially when the minimum wage is so far from being a living wage, and when we don't know how much more the next Congress will raise it by, if at all. Our next president, whoever it will be, will need to lead - not follow Congress - on a living wage, free childcare, healthcare coverage for all, and free college.

A living wage is the first family value we need to redress.

http://www.rimaregas.com/2016/05/on-the-fightfor15-realdonaldtrump-is-ni...

An exception would be the American Standard "clinger" commercial which shows a woman "clinging" to the back of a man while saying "I love you" repeatedly.. cut to bathroom scene where the man gets to "flush" the clingy woman away, problem solved. This is based upon the old joke comparing woment to toilet paper. Still gets airplay on HGTV!
to be more specific, the dupe is always a white male. Only group that can be made fun of without someone raising a ruckus.

For the record, I believe the flammability of the temple and the fact that the doors seemed to be sealed would indicate that Jorah and Daario had prepped the scene for Dany's admittedly awesome moment.

As for Sansa, love that she seems so strong and determined now, but still annoyed that we have to see it linked to her rape. It's a bit of a creative trope, and it's not like we needed to justify Sansa's rage and maturity after everything else she's been through.
